Andy, you missed my point.   I never said you should not be asking
question=
s.  What I said was that you should change your tone.  It's
the tone of voi=
ce that is the problem.

n for the group.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Ken,
> 
> The concept of "NEAT", that you have shared with the rest of us,=
 is a 
> worthy and substantial contribution worthy of praise. And I have 
=
> openly stated as much on more than one occasion. But as I am sure 
> that=
 you are aware, a concept once let loose, is free to become more 
> that wh=
at may have been originally envisioned. 
> 
> I am indeed aware of the work=
 involved in using NEAT for everyday 
> engineering tasks, and making subst=
antial upgrades to the source code 
> infrastructure to unlock its potentia=
l (i.e. greater than a man-year).
> 
> I'm confident in the statement that =
each proposed update suggested to 
> date has already been accomplished (on=
 NEAT, not HyperNEAT). It would 
> be an error to assume otherwise. So I ha=
ve more than a concept of 
> whats involved.
> 
> The problem, if you want =
to characterize it as such, is that my 
> efforts are directed towards ever=
yday engineering tasks which are not 
> public in nature, and the burden of=
 writing papers is substantially 
> greater than just the writing. The expe=
riments are the everyday jobs 
> that need to get done.
> 
> Your efforts a=
re not unappreciated. But when you put something 
> forward with associated=
 claims, its reasonable to assume that you 
> have done your homework and a=
re in a position to answer reasonable 
> questions as they relate to your c=
laims.
> 
> Asking questions such as:
> 
> 1) What benchmarks against known=
 quantities, have you made 
> comparisons against your claims, to help us u=
nderstand where in the 
> AI landscape we should place your claims,
> 
> 2)=
 What computational cost comparisons have you performed against 
> other kn=
own quantities, to help us understand what the costs of your 
> claims are.=

> 
> These are not adversarial questions. They are the normal types of 
> =
questions that are routinely addressed in the body of a technical 
> paper =
or presentation making various claims.
> 
> If you fail to answer the quest=
ions up front in the technical 
> presentation/paper itself, it is reasonab=
le to expect follow-on 
> questions in an attempt to nail these issues down=
. If you neglect to 
> answer these questions, it is also a reasonable expe=
ctation others 
> will wonder why.
> 
> It is my opinion that the concept o=
f NEAT has so much more potential 
> than you have exercised publically to =
date. 
> 
> For whatever your reasons are, perhaps as simple as alignment w=
ith 
> research interests, you have left a lot on the table. And that is 
>=
 your right. It would just be more helpful to all if you would be more 
> f=
orthcoming in regards to the bounds of your agenda, and provide 
> reasonab=
le answers to questions related to your claims and 
> presentations, so tha=
t they may be promptly and properly classified, 
> rather than discovering =
them after the fact in a protracted manner.
> 
> Nobody said being the big =
dog was easy!
> 
> Respectfully,
> Andy Carl
> 
>
